tip.text:
This sweet and pokey independent bookshop on Lower Clapton Road proves that wonderful things often come in small packages. You’ll find an extensive selection upstairs, ranging from contemporary fiction to gorgeous coffee table books - while the downstairs room, complete with couch, offers vintage Penguin books, first editions and vinyl to boot.

Pages of Hackney also stage a number of events: from book readings to photography exhibitions, and are proud to have hosted talks from the likes of China Mielville and Melissa Benn in the past. Get down and help keep printed word alive!

The unremarkable door leading to a dark flight of stairs next to the Spar on Chatsworth Road does little to prepare you for the eye-popping beauty that awaits at the top. You’ll enter into a dimly lit bar where speckled mirrors, a sweeping curved ceiling, copper pineapple bar lamps and plush, chesterfield benches will transport you through time and space to 1920s Hollywood, and a rendezvous with someone glamorous and seductive. Or that dude you met on Happn.

The art deco aesthetic continues into the theatre where an abundance of red velvet and extremely comfortable armchairs will settle you in nicely. The only risk is feeling so at home that you end up falling asleep - especially with the recommended carafe of Borough Wines’ malbec. £5 tickets on Monday’s ain’t bad either.

It’s hard to sum up how much we rate this place - we even considered keeping it a secret, until we remembered the main purpose of our employment. In a space perfectly utilising the edgy-industrial surrounds of the railway arch it finds itself in, you'll find an audio-lounge, restaurant (with changing kitchen residencies), vinyl store and art bookshop.

While away the hours sipping on a something at the bar; nodding your nut at a Saturday record shop in-store from in-house record label BBE; or tucking into something delicious from their low-lit, chic restaurant space. You get the sense that this is more of a passion project than a flagrant money-maker - it's often fairly tranquil and we get the feeling that's how they like it. Oops.

It might be a firm favourite of hen parties and young 'uns, but Wonderland Ceramics is a soothing place to while away a rainy afternoon. The cafe is, you might have guessed, inspired by Alice in Wonderland, with illustrations covering the walls and candles coming out of tea cups. Come in, choose some of the readymade plates, bowls or mugs and give them a thorough, good and proper, committed bit of painting. That'll set you back about £15, and you can collect the pieces a few days later.

They serve tea, coffee and a few snacks whilst you can also BYOB for a small corkage fee. And if you wanna try your hand at the wheel, pottery classes are also available.

listing.name: The Viktor Wynd Museum of Curiosities
listing.subtitle: Surreal Oddities

tip.text:
Imagine if every object you ever found rare, magical or beautiful in any way was put inside a small and dark basement of wonder in Hackney. For us, that would include plenty of Daily Sport newspapers from the early 00s. Luckily Viktor Wynd - a collector with no real time for categorisation or labelling - has a slightly more imaginative mind and he's created an incoherent vision of the world at this surreal museum on Mare Street.

The basement is full of all sorts: from priceless marvels of the natural and scientific worlds like dodo bones to the interesting aesthetics of McDonald's Happy Meal toys; master etchings to prison inmates doodles and pretty much anything else you can imagine. There's also an art gallery upstairs which puts on different shows, normally of the surreal variety.

Entry is £5 which includes a cup of tea, and £2.50 on Thursdays between 6pm-10pm.

A place to get your game face on and feel right at home. Modelled on Tokyo's gamer cafes, this is a place to 'drink, relax and play'. Dojo likes doing all of that, but we've never tried them all at once. There are board games, retro arcade games and collaborative spaces where you can play on their consoles with other gamer sorts. Their drinks list is also game-inspired with 'World of Barcraft' and 'Rum Total War' among the strong bevvies on offer.

Think of Bethnal Green and you might not immediately be envisioning yourself stripped to the waist, with sweat trickling down your face, contemplating the meaning of life. But that could be the reality at the York Hall Spa experience, one of the most affordable spas in town.

Though they offer a range of treatments here, the Thermal Spa experience is the golden ticket, set in one of London's oldest Turkish baths. For three hours you can run (don't run) wild, dipping into two aroma steam rooms, Turkish baths (Tepidarium, Caldarium and Laconium), a sauna, ice fountain, monsoon shower, bucket shower, plunge pool, Hammam and a relaxation lounge. You'll be getting hot, cold and wet in every way known to man. This comes in at £26, but be warned, the service and organisation here can occasionally reflect that budget price.

Remember when little orphan Annie with her red curly hair went to the cinema with Mr Warbucks, and it just looked sick, with all that luxe decor and red velour seating. Well, Rio Cinema is kinda like that. This Grade II listed Art Deco building is home to a 1930s auditorium that's got some seriously sweepin' curves, red velvet seats, atmospheric pre-show music and long red curtains that swish back before the film starts.

With all these bougie adjectives, you'd be forgiven for thinking this was some high-end, money grabbing machine. But oh how wrong you are honey. Rio Cinema is London's longest operating community cinema, having been not-for-profit for the last 40 years. In upkeep with its community vibes, they play host to educational school screenings, fundraising events and various films festivals.

This is a refuge for those out there struggling with the realities of adulthood and in need of a quick fix of nostalgia. Oh hey, everyone! It's a history of toys; a smallish museum that's been amassing childhood-related objects since 1872 and displaying them as a record of how kids have been entertained since kids were allowed to have fun.

In a vast, ornate hall that feels somewhat like a train station, are all the classic toys from over the years - from puppet theatres from the 1970s, to Victorian praxinoscopes; Barbie dolls to Playstations. There isn't that much info here and it doesn't take longer than 45 minutes to take in, but it's still a welcome throwback that's probably geared more towards adults than kids themselves. If you don’t like children or being reminded that you were once a child, do not come here.

Shining bright is this friendly boozer which deals largely in decent pub fare (including our favourite combo of Sunday Roast and Bloody Mary) and an eclectic evening roster of entertainment. Expect DJ sets, disco nights, LGBT affairs, karaoke sing-alongs and a Tuesday pub quiz which has been voted one of the best around. You get extra points for dancing during the music round, apparently.

London's great and all, but there's a distinct lack of cliffs dotted around. Climbing buildings just isn't the same. Mile End Climbing Wall sorts all that - they've got a huge range of different skill-level walls, and top instructors to get you zipping up and down sheer surfaces in no time.You can have a £20 taster session to see if it's for you, with special bouldering courses available too.

Set up back in 2014, Draughts is London's first dedicated board game cafe and they take it pretty seriously indeed. Tucked away off Kingsland Road within the obligatory classic Hackney Arch, you pay £5, grab one of the 600 (!!) different board games and get to it. That's right, 600. That includes pretty much every good game ever invented and a few shit ones too. There are also lots of snacks, sarnies, soft drinks and hard drinks on offer to keep you focused (and spending money).

It's possible to book on weekdays, whilst weekends are first come first serve. It can get pretty noisy in here though, so if it's a busy one our tip would be to choose a game you know roughly how to play.

address.line1: Unit 8, Canalside, Here East, East Bay Ln

tip.text:
Video games, meet beer. Beer, video games. Oh, you guys already met? Oh, you go way back? Oh you're the best combo since Mario and Luigi?

Getting sloshed and competitive with your mates has always been fun, but now the good people of Hackney Wick can do so within the confines of this fancy bar, right on the river. This is the follow up to a well established bar/arcade (barcade) in Peckham, and while more spacious and a little fancier, Four Quarters East still holds all the nostalgic charm of the original.

The walls are lined with a wide range of retro machines from pin ball to Pac-man, and the bar is stocked with a decent selection of craft bevs and cocktails. What's more, with £3.50 pints at happy hour (weekdays 5-7), you can do some mid-week pwning on the cheap. Nice.

It might not have the biggest walls about, but size isn't everything. Right? This centre, a former printers, is all about bouldering, and they've got blocs from the easy to the very difficult indeed. There are bouldering socials three times a week if you're looking to make some pals, and there's a very friendly, communal vibe here if that's the kind of thing you're into. It's £10 during peak times, £7.50 off-peak.

If you look in the bedrooms of other cinemas, you'll probably find posters of Genesis on the walls. This is what indie cinemas aspire to be: it's a swish, beautifully decorated space that's been designed by a couple of film-set designers; there's a nice cafe and bar where local Mile Enders rub shoulders with arty sorts seeking cheap cinematic thrills; and tickets are cheap. Real cheap. It's £5 on Mondays and £10 the rest of the days. There are 5 screens to choose from and Room 5 is a boutique special with cosy armchairs and its own bar.

Want to see the UK's largest board game cafe? That's rhetorical of course, who wouldn't want to see that. Proceed Clockwise is a large, light and airy place for getting into some unnecessarily tense and competitive action with people you previously considered friends. 100 people can fit in here to tackle all the games you'd reasonably expect from the classic to the contemporary to the way-too-complicated-to-try-and-learn-on-a-tipsy-Friday-night.

Sharing boards and some simple pizzas provide the sustenance alongside coffee and craft beers, and the cost for sitting in is £5.

It's hard not to get a lil' lump in the throat thinking about Rich Mix. At a time when British society seems pretty divided, this is an altruistic melting pot of arts and creativity; a charity and social enterprise that houses the creative talents of people from all countries and cultures.

In a former leather factory spanning five floors, it puts on basically everything you can imagine: spoken word, gigs, theatre, dance, art shows and film screenings in its three screen cinema. You'll never really know what is going on there from week to week and that's the charm of it. Cultural diversity is what this huge institution is all about and we're all for it.

This place is a bit of a dream for the true lovers of cinema, in the most highbrow sense we could possibly imagine. The intention of Close-Up - a library, archive, cinema and cafe - is to 'make film culture and history accessible through its collection,' which is a slightly loftier ambition than selling some popcorn and tickets to the latest Nicholas Cage romp.

The cinema itself is a small room with a single screen and around 40 or so seats, and the type of films they show are seminal ones that shaped the art of cinema and its history in some way. You might not recognise the title, but it's important, trust us. All films are shown in 16mm or 35mm and we should also mention that there are some 19,000 film titles in its archive! There's a bar and cafe too for drinks and nibbles and looking like you're a well-educated film buff.

Like a Turkey voting for Christmas, advocating a tech-free bookshop where phones are banned might not seem the most logical thing for us to do, but we're mavericks out here. Libreria is a different kind of bookshop from the stylish cats at Second Home: a cosy, design-led bookshop where the idea is to discover new books and ideas and get into some interdisciplinary thinking. No lattes, no wifi.

Evidently a response to the constant noise of the digital age, this place has gentle yellow lighting, light wood and more books than seem plausible. The shelves were designed by Slade School artists, there's a whisky bar for events and a printing press downstairs. Take a little break from all that tech - but then come straight back to us afterwards.

The speedy evolution of Tottenham continues apace here with a bouldering and yoga studio set up in an old warehouse. Oh, you're not excited? How about if we tell you it's London's largest bouldering centre! That sure got your attention, eh?

Here you'll find hundreds of bouldering problems but also plenty of places to hang about and socialise in and talk about whatever is on your mind - we suggest bouldering related topics to avoid looking like a fraud. There's also a yoga studio, a fully equipped changing room and a nicely stocked café.
